deliberation: I checked the vocative 'בן־אָדָם' and the commissioning formula 'כה אמר אדני יהוה' as well as the title 'נשיא ראש משך ותבל'. All function here as standard prophetic address and political designation without a clear figurative transfer of meaning.

I considered whether the movement verbs could be purely literal military description or also figurative of divine coercion. The combination 'turn you around' and 'drive you on' strongly evokes an image of an animal or object being forced along, functioning as a metaphor for God’s control over Gog’s campaign.

instances.english_text: I will turn you around and drive you on, and I will take you from the far north
target: Gog and his military advance toward Israel
vehicle: an animal or vehicle being turned and driven by a master
forcibly controlled physical movement
everyday physical control
ground: loss of self-direction and being compelled by a stronger will
absolute subjection to another’s guidance
divine sovereignty over nations
posture: YHWH depicting His manipulation of Gog
assertive, coercive stance toward an enemy
instances.explanation: God’s sovereign redirection of Gog’s invasion is pictured as physically turning and driving an animal or vehicle, emphasizing Gog’s lack of autonomy.

deliberation: The actions described could be literal combat, but in prophetic style the disarming of Gog functions as a picture of total neutralization of power. The bow and arrows stand for military strength, and striking them from the hands metaphorically depicts God removing Gog’s capacity to wage war.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִכֵּיתִ֥י קַשְׁתְּךָ֖ מִיַּ֣ד שְׂמֹאולֶ֑ךָ וְחִצֶּ֕יךָ מִיַּ֥ד יְמִינְךָ֖ אַפִּֽיל

posture: YHWH’s action of stripping Gog of weapons
humiliating, overpowering stance toward the invader
instances.explanation: The disarming of Gog’s hands symbolizes God removing Gog’s power; the bow and arrows metonymically represent Gog’s entire military force.

deliberation: The verse describes Gog’s fall and then his being given as food to birds and beasts. While fallen corpses can literally be eaten, the language is stylized and anticipates the sacrificial-feast imagery in vv. 17–20. I treat the depiction of Gog as food for carrion as a metaphoric image of utter defeat and dishonor.

instances.hebrew_text: לְעֵ֨יט צִפּ֧וֹר כׇּל־כָּנָ֛ף וְחַיַּ֥ת הַשָּׂדֶ֖ה נְתַתִּ֥יךָ לְאׇכְלָֽה

being rendered unusable and exposed to desecration
totality of divine judgment
instances.explanation: Portraying Gog as food for carrion graphically conveys the completeness and shame of his defeat; the scale of the image has a hyperbolic flavor.

deliberation: This verse restates the fall of Gog 'on the surface of the field' and affirms divine speech. The phrase functions as a locative description without a distinct figurative transfer. I did not find a clear metaphor, idiom, or other figure beyond the general martial context inherited from v. 4.

I weighed whether 'send fire' is literal conflagration or figurative for comprehensive judgment. In prophetic diction, fire often symbolizes destructive divine judgment, which may include but is not limited to literal burning. Here it stands for the total devastation God brings on Magog and the coastlands.

instances.english_text: And I will send a fire against Magog and against those who dwell secure in the coastlands

natural destructive force
ground: consuming, unstoppable, and purging destruction
removal of security and exposure to ruin
severity of divine punishment
posture: YHWH’s hostile intervention against secure nations
instances.explanation: Fire functions as a metaphor and metonymy for total, consuming judgment that destroys the security of Magog and the coastlands.

deliberation: I looked at 'my holy name' being made known and not profaned. In Hebrew idiom, 'name' regularly stands for reputation or manifested character. The verse also speaks of God as 'holy in Israel.' The clearest figure is the metonymy of 'name' for God’s public reputation and presence among His people and the nations.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאֶת־שֵׁ֨ם קׇדְשִׁ֜י אוֹדִ֗יעַ בְּתוֹךְ֙ עַמִּ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וְלֹא־אַחֵ֥ל אֶת־שֵׁם־קׇדְשִׁ֖י ע֑וֹד

instances.explanation: ‘Name’ functions idiomatically and metonymically for God’s reputation and public self-manifestation, which He will ensure is no longer desecrated.

deliberation: The verse announces the arrival of 'the day' God had spoken of. This is typical prophetic temporal language; the 'day' is a conceptual period of judgment, but that usage is conventional and not elaborated with imagery here. I did not find a distinct metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond the standard prophetic idiom of a decreed 'day.'

The burning of weapons as fuel for seven years could in principle be literal within the vision, yet the length and detail serve to underscore the enormity of Gog’s defeat. This functions hyperbolically to convey abundance of spoil and reversal of fortunes, transforming instruments of war into sources of domestic benefit.

instances.explanation: The picture of weapons serving as fuel for seven years hyperbolically portrays the sheer magnitude of the defeated army and Israel’s complete reversal of fortunes.

deliberation: This continues v. 9: no need to gather wood because weapons suffice, and Israel will plunder their plunderers. The lack of wood-gathering intensifies the hyperbolic image of abundance. The phrase 'they will despoil those who despoiled them' is a rhetorical reversal but not strictly metaphorical in itself.

instances.explanation: The idea that weapons alone suffice for all firewood extends the hyperbolic picture of overwhelming plunder and the ironic conversion of war-tools into fuel.

deliberation: The verse gives geographic and onomastic details about Gog’s burial valley. The naming 'Valley of Gog’s Multitude' is symbolic but not a figurative transfer—rather it is an explanatory name. I did not discern a distinct metaphor, idiom, or personification beyond the literal description of a burial site.

Seven months of burial work is lengthy and could have hyperbolic force, but the primary figurative element is in 'to cleanse/purify the land.' The land is treated as something bearing impurity from corpses, extending ritual purity language to the soil itself, which functions as a kind of personification/metaphor.

instances.explanation: The land is spoken of as needing purification, personifying it and using ritual-cleansing metaphor for the restoration of the community’s space after judgment.

deliberation: I examined 'it shall be for them for a name' and 'the day I am glorified.' The former uses 'name' metonymically for renown; the latter is a standard way of speaking of God’s honor being publicly displayed. The clearest figure is 'name' for reputation.

instances.explanation: ‘Name’ stands metonymically for reputation; the day of God’s self-glorification becomes the source of Israel’s public renown.

deliberation: The verse explains the appointment of men who bury the remaining dead 'to cleanse it.' As in v. 12, the land is treated as something that can be cleansed, employing ritual purity language metaphorically with a mild personification of the land.

deliberation: The verse gives procedural detail: travelers see a human bone and mark it until it is buried. The language is straightforward, without evident metaphor, idiom, or other figures beyond the ongoing context of ritual purification.

Naming a city 'Multitude' is symbolic, but not itself a metaphor in the sentence. The closing 'and they shall cleanse the land' reprises the figurative purification language seen earlier—land as object of cleansing using ritual vocabulary.

deliberation: Here God addresses birds and beasts, summoning them to 'my sacrifice' on the mountains, to eat flesh and drink blood. This extends v. 4’s image into a full sacrificial feast metaphor: the slaughtered enemy army is conceptualized as a sacrifice God prepares for carrion.

deliberation: Warriors and princes are listed alongside rams, lambs, goats, and bulls, 'fatlings of Bashan.' This clearly maps human leaders onto sacrificial animals, continuing the sacrificial-feast metaphor in zoomorphic fashion.

deliberation: The verse continues the feast imagery: eating fat 'to satiety' and drinking blood 'to intoxication' from God’s sacrifice. This heightens the metaphor and uses hyperbole to stress abundance of victims and completeness of judgment.

deliberation: Two common figures occur: 'my glory' being set/placed among the nations, and 'my hand which I set upon them.' Glory is God’s manifested presence; hand is a metonymy for power. Both expressions visualize divine action in anthropomorphic terms.

deliberation: The verse states that Israel will 'know that I am YHWH their God' from that day onward. This is a covenant formula signaling relational knowledge, but it is not here elaborated with imagery or unconventional wording. I did not isolate a distinct figurative expression requiring analysis.

I noted three idiomatic figures: 'house of Israel' (for the people), 'I hid my face from them,' and 'they fell by the sword.' The most salient figurative devices are (a) the anthropomorphic idiom of hiding the divine face, and (b) 'falling by the sword' as a standard metonymic idiom for dying violently in war.

instances.explanation: God is described as hiding His face, a personifying metaphor for withholding His favorable presence and protection because of Israel’s treachery.

deliberation: This verse repeats the idiom of God hiding His face and mentions dealing with Israel according to their impurity and transgressions. The key figurative element remains the personifying anthropomorphic phrase 'I hid my face from them.'

deliberation: I examined 'restore the fortunes (captivity) of Jacob' and 'be zealous for My holy name.' The first is a well-known idiom for reversing disaster and restoring wellbeing; the second repeats the 'holy name' metonymy from v. 7. I treat 'restore the fortunes' as the central idiom here.

deliberation: The notable expression is 'they will bear their shame,' a common Hebrew idiom/metaphor for experiencing ongoing disgrace as a kind of burden or clothing one carries. The rest is a straightforward description of dwelling securely.

deliberation: The key expression is 'I will be sanctified in them in the sight of many nations.' Here God’s holiness is 'manifested' through His dealings with Israel—holiness is not a ritual act but a public recognition. This extends 'sanctify' in a metaphorical sense to mean 'show to be holy.'

deliberation: The verse relates exile and regathering and states that none will be left behind. The phrasing is straightforward without distinctive figurative idioms beyond the usual theological language of exile and gathering. I did not identify a discrete metaphor or personification requiring separate treatment.

Two strong figures appear: (1) 'I will not hide My face from them anymore' repeating the anthropomorphic idiom of divine withdrawal, and (2) 'I pour out My spirit upon the house of Israel,' a metaphor of effusion for abundant bestowal of God’s life-giving presence.
